element_texts.text:
Your "Boy"
Capt Cole 32d U.S.C.Y.
Geo. M. Templeton
HEISS'
GALLERY,
No. 1028 Chestnut Street

Newberry Library logo stamped in lower right corner

POCKET SCRATCH BOOK NO 2
gentle slope & up a gentle slope & got out to the next ridge only to find another at our same level still in advance - After going on & on until we had thus passed four ridges & seeing nothing but slopes still in advance the affair became seriously monotonous - There seemed no end to the ridges. We had fully demonstrated the impracticability of this route for for though it might be passed with wagons it  would be with extreme difficulty by [?] teams.

back to unclear the wagons - Hurried these up a little & got across the valley ahead of the fire & struck down stream for the stockade - Arrived there about 2 pm - The wagons about half an hour later - The stockade which is about 400 yds from my camp was built last winter? by the [Miners?]] whom Mix brought out this spring. It is 80 feet square with flanking projections at each corner. The upright logs are 12 to 14 feet high above the ground - not squared  the openings between the

gold, which I myself saw panned out & brought in with me to send to Genl Crook - After a very pleasant interview? I came away - leaving them very happy -  They had this morning set fire to the grass on their claim to facilitate their work in fixing stakes &c   While I was with them the wind arose & the fire spread with great rapidity, so much so as to preclude any possibility of making a camp in that valley near its course - So I determined to come down stream, & went

then set out down the ravine - Spaulding is a great fellow for short cuts & thinking I was wasting too much time in zigzagging he made a short cut for the bottom of the ravine. The result was that he not only missed the spring, the drink & the lunch - but was floundering about trying to get down a 30 foot precipice without braking his neck. He at last accomplished the job? by turning? the obstacle & soon after I found him - He was

unclear alt. its differences unclear the latter.  The slope down was an angle of about 45º  but by zigzagging we managed to get down without dismounting - At the bottom I found a lovely spring of the best water I have tasted since I left Omaha - I drank about a gallon of it for I was heated to red heat - it being terribly hot today - I mixed a little to prevent its injuring me - took my lunch

birch, quaking asp, plum & cherry bushes - & the sides a mass of strawberry vines in bloom - To get along was a work of constant difficulty - sometimes we had to shin along the side of the canon- to cross boulders, or huge rafts of fallen timber - sometimes we went over logs, sometimes under & I was constantly expecting to come on a sudden fall of 15 or 20 feet, which would force us to go back & look for another pass - Most fortunately never such occurred & after an interminable time we

now in a canon the north wall of which was almost an absolute precipice? The South wall was in some places almost a precipice in other places it sloped away at an angle of from 60 to 75 degrees - The canon was not less than 1000 feet deep in some places not 500 feet wide. The bottom was a narrow V averaging some 20 feet wide - in some places not six feet - filled with huge boulders, between? masses of storm-fallen trees which

limestone a full of caves  & would appear to be the houses of the bear tribe - but we saw no sign whatever in the canon. Jenney returned soon after us. He went straight up the valley of this creek & found a good road out? what he thinks is a high plain, by which we can turn the Hills & get unclear We will start the day after tomorro-- The unclear are nearly done. Tomorro will finish them & I can leave this camp safe if the captain will only keep on the watch - I was great disappointed in

got through all right - We arrived in camp 5l30 pretty well used up, having ridden up & down at least 30 miles & clambered or scrambled on foot 5 or 6 - Spaulding for one shot & dragged a Black Tail very nicely - I got no shot. Game was very scarce though we saw plenty of fresh elk & deer tracks - We were surprised to find no bear - The walls of the canon an of mountain

Camp Jenney - 22- June 9, 75. I was kept awake for a long time last night thinking of the problem of our advance. I finally decided to move with all the force I can transport & after finding a new camp to send back for the Cos left unclear -- Early in the morning I met? Mr Jenney. He opened the conversation by proposing to take a command & go back down the Beaver to 104 & run out that line first - I explained

the timber of the mountains. In the foot hills & low valleys there are very fair pines. Some 2 feet in diameter & probably 20 ft to the limbs - On the high hills it is very scarce? & is besides wind shaken. Fires have made huge rifts through it & we travelled for about 4 miles through a mass of blown down trees? from 3 in to a foot in diameter - The pine is all Rocky Mountain pine, which is very poor timber at the best - No gold. All secondary rocks & formations

games of cribbage & whist & beat all my opponents - The Herald reporter Davenport asked to mess? with me on this trip - I declined - telling him very frankly that I could not have a man with me all the time with whom I must be constantly on my guard in conversation - That my mess was composed of my staff offs with whom I constantly conversed very freely - especially at meals & that his presence would not be satisfactory to us.

to him that it would be only a loss of time & finally convinced him that the best they could do would be to go on & get another camp.  He is not a strong man & I soon had him fixed - I at once gave orders for unclear & 3 Cos to move tomorro am -- with necessary details - Went up to the unclear which are completed - all but the platform on one - Finished up all preliminary arrangements - played several

of whom is continually employed by him, the other by me - Every other person is a part of the expedition & must go along.  Even at the expense of the secrecy to which he aspires - He was but little satisfied & said that was very unfortunate that no one should discover gold before he did & that he must make the first report -- Soon after he left, Davenport came to me to ask me to recommend a man who could unclear on to take in to

I believe he was satisfied with my reasons - Had a nice nap - very grateful after my fatigue of yesterday & feel perfectly well & capable of going on another trip -  Jenney came over after dinner.  He is morbidly anxious lest some one should be ahead of him in reporting Gold -- Asked me if I would please prevent any "outsiders" from going along - Told him that there were but two outsiders in Camp - one

I told him I could not help him - He then told me that Jenney had a man, brought out here expressly to carry out dispatches for him & finally said, "I can afford to pay more than any body else - & I think I will go to Jenney's man & see if I can't get him to go back on Jenney for money" -- I told him that they were all Kilkenny Cats & might use? each other up or beat & bribe as suited them.  But I rejoice that I am a soldier of success

Ft Laramie a Herald dispatch announcing the first discovery of gold.  I told him that he could not have a soldier, & that the only other man was "California Joe" he of whom Custer speaks so highly & who is a worthless vagabond * [inserted: subsequently changed this opinion]].   Davenport said he was afraid to trust him, that he would take his money & then carry in dispatches from other reporters.

men in the U.S. care one jot who reports it -  Dr. Lane & Morton came back this afternoon from a leave I gave them three days ago - They have been to Harney's Peak & made a wide circuit through the Hills - Jeremy is mad as a hornet that I let them go - though he has said nothing to me - They give no very satisfactory account of the Hills - The country is extremely broken & very difficult every way -

in civil life depends on such unclear-able dirty practices that Jeremy & the Herald man were disposed to put in operation against each other. Nor do I want to be a reporter if through it I fail to be a gentleman.  One would suppose that a matter of life or death depended on which should be first to report gold which I doubt it Fifty

Camp 12 - Spring - June 9, 1875. Got off at 6.45 which was doing remarkably considering that we were breaking up a permanent camp - Took the 2 cos 2nd Cavy- Spaulding & Hall's & [unclear: Wessels?]] of 3rd Cavy. This is much the largest & unclear company - As it was to have the lead today, I sent out an officer & 20 men yesterday afternoon to fix the road near camp

They think there is mineral on that side & say that the other portion of the hills is worthless  Unclear name & old man Bullock tried to make Dr Macgillicuddy tight this afternoon & both fell in the experiment while the Dr went off unclear--story about practical joke? Got off joke on Kinny who ran away from Spaudling & I yesterday thinking we were Indians.  Morton & Dr got no game -

Captain - & do as little work & as slowly as possible. The eastern mountains pour numerous beautiful looking brooklets to the main creek. The water is filled with gypsum salt unclear & tho' cool & tolerably palatable is perfect poison to my stomach & keeps me sickish all the time - Besides this these streams? run? in ravines which had to be cut down or make bogs which have to be corduroy' d.  Trout worked like a beaver & he is a most invaluable man not only

It was done, but so badly that it took us nearly two hours to get it in condition for the wagons to pass.  From then on we had nothing but trouble until 1 pm.  Our route led up the creek which being dammed by beavers to a bog, or having steep & deep banks is practically impassable except by bridging.  Unclear:  Isiaah? is a half hearted kind of a man with no snap to him & the men take their tour? how the

of streams is beautifully green with grass & graceful with trees & shrubbery. On each side rise ranges of mountains 1000 to 1200 feet high. Their tops covered with the thick growth of pine which gives the name of the "Black Hills". Below this many of the hills show a face of several hundred feet of no? sandstone, below this is a belt of very uniform thickness, 20 to 40 feet, of limestone. Below this again several hundred feet of a red clay filled with gypsum and south? of all unclear -

possessing wonderful energy but great practical ability. By 1 pm we had passed the last bog & entered on the hard level bottom land of the creek following up the left bank. The road on is elegant, a great Indian trail as large as a wagon road - Warren passed over it many years ago before the war, but his trail is entirely obliterated. The scenery today has been really very grand & beautiful. The valley owing to the number

She was so grateful? graceful? of her brood that she let us come quite close & at last took [[unclear] with the little ones in a thicket? of bushes - I would not let anyone hurt her - About 12 miles from last camp we crossed to the right bank of the ravine now dry - & rising rapidly on a series of long green treeless slopes. Came at 4.30 to a beautiful spring with enough water for all the animals & went with? camp - Distance today 14 miles - wood water & grass excellent & plenty 0 The water kept me sick today & I had to get

Below all is the green valley & the combination & variety of colors, make as fine a picture as one may see in a long journey - About ten miles from Camp Jenney the stream gave out, that is it has no water in it.  Just before we came to the head springs - on farther the place where the water which has been for many miles running under the sand of the bed, makes it appearance. I came suddenly on a mallard duck with a brood of nine little downy young ones -

& Trout insisted in going out after them though it rained hard & is as dark as Erebus - I gave him all the men he wanted but I wouldn't go out tonight for all the Texas cattle in the country. No game today - I wanted to go about seven miles further but we lost so much time this am that I could not - Overturned one wagon (one  of the Hdqr) & broke the tongue of the Drs ambulance (Dr Jaquette) very small casualties considering the circumstances. As it happens both occurred on comparatively poor ground from the carelessness of the Drivers.  All are in - repairs completed

out several times - & have not felt well at all in the bowels - tho' first rate everywhere else - James, my no-account "Nig" got to fooling with my gun today & broke the hair trigger - that I shall not be able to use it until after I get to the next permanent camp.  The sun set cloudy  & with every appearance of a storm & just after dark a sharp storm with thunder & lightning came on & now at 9 pm it is raining in heavy showers with pretty sharp lightning. The cattle were stampeded by the thunder

Camp 13 - Head of branch of Red Water creek - June 10th 1875. Rainy all night but bright & clear in the morning. Broke camp 5.30 am and travelled due north following an old Indian trail which led us thro' open pine woods covered long rounded slopes - On our right was the canon of the Beaver (or Spauldings) creek - here at least 500 feet deep & inaccessible to anything but bird or bear. Our route was not only

Trout has just reported that the herd all recovered - & the extra sentinels over them- He is a just a little disposed to make th emost of his work & I greatly disposed to give him full credit for all he does - but when he came after about 25 minutes absence & reported that he had followed the herd three (3) miles, I couldn't quite swallow it. He may have thought it felt three miles & would likely have been a dozen to me - but he could not have gone a mile - Still stormy & bleak

terminating in the valley of Spauldings creek bounded on each side by mountains over 1000 feet.  At our feet a vast plain apparently limitless to West & N. West. On the north some miles ahead a belt of timber - on our immediate right - or east- an impassible chasm of 500 feet & on the other side of it mountains rising up 1000 feet yet higher & covered with a dense forest of pine.  Seven miles from camp the trail led to the breech of the chasm & we found all the sides not actually precipices covered with quaking

excellent for travelling but was through a most beautiful country. About 3 miles from camp crossed Warren trail at a spring at which e camped (No 13) -  a mile further on we got onto a magnificent plain bare of timber & extending to the north'west as far as we could see - It was about four miles across on the trail we came almost perfectly level - The topographical features presented here are remarkable  Behind us the long slopes

Leaving this wild & most interesting spot, we passed along the brink of the chasm & through a quaking asp thicket for about a mile when the trail suddenly dived down into its depths. I had sent Joe forward a half hour before & when he met me he was in despair. Recommended me to go into camp & send out to find a way - as the route before us was impassible for wagons - Leaving the Com'd I struck off on the trail - down into the depths. It was truly impassible for we could with difficulty get down

asp. sometimes called "bitter" & sometimes called "white" cottonwood. Better still, from the steep sides of the cliff burst forth numerous streams of beautiful & perfectly pure water.  Here we stopped for a half an hour to wait for the wagons. I picked a great variety of flowers all very alpine in their characteristics. There is a slight growth of dwarf juniper & also of mountain ivy, both of which rarely get much below the limit of perpetual snow -

backbone was narrowest I spied symptoms of water on our left & crossing down to the valley we came to a lovely little stream, rushing out from a dense thicket of quaking asp.  Here we regaled ourselves with the most delicious water & took a drink of whiskey to our good success so far in route - From this point we made about a mile of climbing still on the divide & were soon rewarded by one of the most magnificent views I have had on the trip. The whole country to the North west & south was spread out at our feet.  To the North

on horseback - Seeing that the fall in the bottom of the canon was very great I had hopes of turning it - & at once struck up the bed. In less than an hour I had found a route & sent Spaulding back for the Com'd. The new route skirted the edge of the canon for about two miles, gradually turning toward the eastward & then to my delight began to crawl up a backbone between the Spauldings Ck Canon's on our right and an unknown ? on our left - When this

of the top of this divide is 7850 feet- above this water or 3050 above our permanent camp - From this elevation I was enabled to study the water shed of the Blk Hills  to the north & west. The stream breaks off to the south - north west & north-east- & I am satisfied that we were on the very back bone of this system of Hills & that with the exception of a few peaks, we were on the highest ground of the Hills.  This supposition will have to be verified later - From this elevation we soon began

west the huge form of the Bear Lodge Butte interlinearly:  all wrong as we after ward found dwarfed every mountain in sight. Inyan Kara of which Custer makes a good deal was 1600 feet below us & scarcely distinguishable except as a flat topped mesa - The Northern rim of the Blk Hills was plainly in view but the northeast & east views were cut off by dense clouds which hung over that section unclear I am sorry to say around to our front.  The elevation

with with the canon than Mr Jenney insisted on turning sharp to the south west following up another branch of the stream we are now on & which proves to be a branch of Red Water Creek - I refused telling him that it would only take in to the divide again not far from where we left The Great Indian Trail this am.  He got angry & pouted like a schoolboy - but I went on my course - I tried to explain to him that the course we had would lead us in a short time to Custer Trail & that with our overloaded wagons & scant provisions we could not so

to go down- & the trail (Indian) instead of following the divide as I hoped - soon after passing the top - plunged down a series of steep hills, which would well try the unclear & capacity of unclear & quarter master - & finally came in to a deep valley - almost a gorge - the sides of which are covered with quaking asp. & the tops occasionally with pine - tho the tops over which we came were nearly bare - Our Indian trail had been going too much to the North and no sooner had we got

came on which soon settled into showers - We donned our waterproofs, built fires & tried to make ourselves comfortable with little success - It hailed & snowed & at 12 when the wagons came up, it was snowing so hard that I determined to go with camp - Going down a short distance I found water & plenty of signs of a camp & soon found that Custer had camped here. The weather was horrible - blowing snowy & raining - Nothing is more disagreeable than to go with camp in a rain storm - but it could not be helped - I found a sheltered

rampaging around such a difficult country as this - He didn't want to strike Custer Trail. He was exploring & wanted to make trails of his own - but with my train I couldn't see the merit of experimenting & kept on for Custer's Trail - About 11 am & less than two miles from where he got "mad" we struck Custers trail - going south west in a valley of which the one we came down is a tributary - Here I stopped again to wait for the wagons. Soon after we stopped a drizzle

covered with quaking asp, pine & spruce - But alas for the "floral" part of it - It is very early spring here. The trees are just budding. Only the hardiest flowers are in bloom - the grass is short. There are few birds & they are not yet paired - on the ridge we fell in with a fine "pack" or covey of spike grouse - at least a dozen birds, apparently not yet thinking of the bonding season. The springs here are very fine & perfectly pure water  The timber rather poor. Grass very backward. The soil appears to be excellent in the valley

nook, perpendicular to the main valley & in which we are sheltered as much as we could hope. But it is a nasty storm & we are having a by no means pleasant experience.  After dinner I got Custer map & Sandy Forsyth's diary & find we are at Custers Camp of 25th July last year at the head of what he calls "Floral Valley" - It is a very pretty little gorge even now, varying from one to two hundred yards in width, bounded by steep hills & sides of which are

the grass is just starting and our poor horses & mules suffer for food, while it is almost impossible to keep the cattle herd from wandering. The spring has really scarcely opened here - the buds barely having started & even the strawberries not being yet in bloom - The Indians lied to Custer when they told him that the grass was good here in March - & his supposition that there was but little snow is also erroneous. The ground is yet wet from the  unclear snow & a deep bed of it was today found on the side of the great canon of Spaulding Ck - Temperature of spring water 41 degrees far. Wood & water excellent - and grass

but from all indications the seasons must be so short as to prevent the raising of any grain or produce except grass. If the country is not mineral it is worth but little - Two months of summer & ten of winter is not a good climate for settlers - Distance today 12 1/2 miles - Considering the country our road was excellent & I have received congratulations from several of the offs. on our success so far especially in today's march.  Geologically we are getting low to the carboniferous formation. May get to bed-rock soon --

The grass was extremely poor & the landscape though beautifully framed & set out was poor & bald. The lovely glades of which Forsyth speaks were yet glades - but the scant green of the valley or gorge & the deeper green of the pine & spruce were the only variations of color - The "valley" soon came to a termination. By a very easy slope & a succession of graceful curves, the route passed from the ascending to a descending grade & almost imperceptibly we found ourselves going down - only a few hundred yards from the divide we came to a splendid spring the true head of Custer's "Castle" Creek

Camp 14. June 11th 1875. Rain & sleet during night with occasional high wind. Slept like a top under a pile of covers - ordered reveille an hour late - Soon after Breakfast the sun came out - kept the tents standing to allow them to dry as much as possible - Wrote in journal & observations - Broke camp 11.15 by which time the tents were finally dry. Our route led up Custer's floral valley 0 Alas for the floral- The trees were scarcely budded, nor did many of the smaller shrubs showed not even swollen buds.

timber being very straight, light & strong is particularly adapted for lodge poles & unclear comes here to get it - Just below this camp was one of the very longest & highest Beaver dams I have ever seen - It was irregular in shape but could not have been less than 400 feet long. It was the beginning of a succession of dams, which cross the stream at short intervals for some miles - At this old camp was also the very coolest spring I have ever seen.  I had no means of taking accurately the temperature but I am sure it was at least 5 degrees cooler than our spring of last

Shortly after we came to an old Indian camp, where all the squaws seem to have devoted themselves to cutting & trimming lodgepoles. There has been at some time a large camp of Indians here - & I could distinguish - & I could distinguish the remains of a Medicine Lodge, so I presume they had been making medicine - All along the route today were remains of Indian camps of last year. They are temporary & all seem to have been devoted to lodge pole making. This little valley affords an abundant growth of spruce on its sides - This

change in the appearance of the country but I think Custer & his party having come through the arid plains of the Little Missouri & the horrible monotony of the Bad lands were ready to believe almost any tolerably nice place a paradise.  We are now encamped at Custer camp of 26 July. It is very pretty & since we have got down hill a little I have had to change my verdict on grass.  For the last 5 miles the grass is superb & we camp on a sward that cannot be beat - We are about 1000 feet below the summits of the bordering hills & about 400

night - The whole route today has been a succession of springs & the water is most delicious -- Going down the valley gradually deepens. The hills on each side are topped by huge masses of carboniferous limestone from which it takes its appropriate name of Castle Creek.  The scenery is fine but not to be compared with that of the middle park or the western face of the Medicine Bow range - Great allowance must be made for differences in season - or I can see that six weeks will make a very great

dry weather & crossed teh creek where he pleased - Every crossing with us is a most serious matter. Quartz has been found today in considerable quantities- some of it seems gold bearing. Jenney is going to stop & work part of tomorrow - The timber has been much burned. That on the mt tops is small - on the sides larger & better - Distance 12 /12 miles - Wagons got with camp at 5.30 pm. Only one or two deer today.

below our camp of last night. I saw some fish in a Beaver dam & hoped they were trout - sent back for my rod & tried - They were chubs - alas?- & I was greatly disappointed - Wagons had a hard day -- The snow & rains of yesterday made the creek bottom almost a bog - & the mules had a dead? pull ever since we left camp.  We have benefited somewhat by Custers work, unclear-- finding our ??? in tolerable repair & several side cuttings which saved us work -- Custer passed on

and came back on the creek again 4 miles below - In spite of the bog I determined to make a route down the creek & started at once - Finding it practicable I sent back one orderly & brought the train through its most frightful & fatiguing day - Bog Bog - all the time - 16 mules on a team & as many men as could get hold prying or lifting the bed out of the mud - I reached this place - Custer camp of July 28 -  at 7 am Spaulding came in with his Co about 9 - & Trout with the wagons & pioneers came in

Camp 15. Woodchuck Creek June 12, 1875.  Broke camp 5.20 and soon after leaving camp this road become a bottomless pit of bog. I got over tolerably well with Trout & we thought we had selected a fair route - Soon after Spaullding attempted to cross & his horse went down to his sides & had to be pulled out with lariats - How Trout ever got the wagons over will be a constant wonder to me - Custer's trail here led off from the creek to make an aimless journey around  a park

to be for tomorrow - For four miles up this little creek the road is bad, boggy, spongy & requiring corduroy frequently - About 6 miles from camp we were attracted by a high bare hill & going to the top were amply repaid for our trouble - The view is more than fine or grand or magnificent - we seemed to be fixed in the center of a circle formed by huge hills & mountains - In the North or East only a few prominent peaks broke the monotony of the general elevation of the "??" - a little to the south of east a huge bare rock towering to an immense

at 12 n. Before arriving however he sent me word that he had broken a wheel & would have to abandon a wagon unless I could go with camp - So I went with Camp - I tried fishing but could get nothing If there are any fish they are surfeited with the millions of young grasshoppers that are drowned? in the stream - It was a long "wait for the wagons" & I was tired of inaction. So as soon as I determined to camp Mr Spaulding unclear & myself rode to the front to see what was

of this most disorderly mass of material - The more I see of the Black Hills & its travel, the more credit I am disposed to give to Custer for his exploration of last year - I find his map remarkably correct & it is of the greatest use to me. Even with it I find it no easy to matter to go where I want - & to him who had nothing but his compass - the capacity of his wagons for ups and downs to direct him - the finding of any route was a success - I am told he had several guides. They are generally a very worthless & unreliable set of

height was said to be Harney's Peak. It was not over ten miles away. The South & South west views were bounded by as ragged & jagged a mass of mountains as I have ever seen & most of them seem to be very high - The interior of this basin was filled with a mass of hill & canon mixed together in the most  indiscernable? manner & apparently without system or order. Generally such a view would give some idea of the water shed, the course of the streams etc but very little can be gained from any study

though in the latter I confess I am disappointed - The grass is splendid here.  As a grazing country it cannot be surpassed. The only doubt about its agricultural value is as to the length of the season. Today we struck for the first time - Gold - undoubtable? unmistakable - It was only a little "show" but it is gold - In ten years the Black Hills will be the home of a numerous & thriving population & all the administrations & Interior Departments cant stop it. It is not an Indian Country They can live in it for only

men at best but in a totally unknown country might possibly be made of use by sending them forward to look out routes - I have one so called guide, Joe Merivale, who was in the Hills 30 years ago & who knows no more about them than a New York Dandy. He has nothing to do as guide but I keep him as interpreter in case I should meet Indians. The country passed today has been very beautiful - It is certainly remarkable for the fertility of the soil of the valleys. - for its picturesque beauty & for its timber

We have seen today some of the Custer Park Country   bare spots in the midst of the black mass of pines - The variety is very pleasing - Mr Jenney wishes to unclear a few days here prospecting. I leave unclear Co with him & go on without a permanent camp with the other two - 15 deer brought with camp today Several others killed but lost - Spaudling knocked one down which got away - Distance 4 1/2 miles - Wood water & grass excellent.

a small portion of the year & being Plains Indians they do not like to go with a country where they cannot ride everywhere they wish to go - They use is as a nursery for game & a fine one it is.  There is too much water -- streams spring out from every hill & the valleys or bottoms are all morasses & when we remember that this spring water has a temperature from 36 to 42 degrees - it will readily be seen that the soil however rich will be kept too cold for agricultural purposes --

seems to have been stuck & to have each got out on its own hook.  The first seven? miles were easily made & in good time - We crossed a divide & struck a stream which Joe says is the head of Spring Ck - which is the origin of the morass spoken of - Once through that we had a good road following Custer over the divide between added interlinearly: Rapid spg spring & French inserted:  wrong Ck - The latter I followed closely - Custer's Trail crosses it some eight or ten times, & a not a good crossing of them all. The trail

Camp 16  Spring Creek Sunday June 13, 1875.  Sent Spaulding's Co out early this am to make road. went out myself 6.30 am leaving orders for camp to break at 9 am. Leaving name of Co that was left behind, unclear relieved us very much giving as his is the "Bug-Stuffers" wagon - Our loads were so light that we could go almost anywhere with little work - Had a D'l devil of a time working Custers trail out of a crevasse/morass? in which almost every wagon

but could do nothing after I got there, the sides of the immense gorge being impassible even for pack mules -- After a hard search for a better fate? I had to yield to imperative necessity - & decided to go back tomorrow to Custer trail - after which I will be guided in any selection of permanent Camp by Circumstances -  The more I see of the country the more disposed I am to give credit to Custer for his march through here - He must have had a corps of guides more reliable than

turned off from the creek & I wishing to make my permanent camp on it followed it down. It got worse & worse & after several bad crossings & a lot of bad road, I sent Spaulding down to look at the prospect.  He returned after an hour & told me it was impossible to go down to the Creek - Still hoping I left him to put the Comd in camp & went down myself for about 4 miles. I can go down with wagons, though it will take a unclear of work

there yet. The scenery is very fine - I went again today to the top of the hill from which I had the fine view yesterday. Hunted a little today with Spaulding, fun?fine? & had a long shot at a bear. I think a Grizzly but a very small one - Spaulding missed a deer - Five ? brought in today - The Elk & black tails have not come up yet. This would be a magnificent hunting in the fall or winter. The whole country is covered with ?-horns? elk or deer -- all the

usual - for they certainly have struck about the only route at all practicable for wagons - As we go south the mountains grow higher - or what amounts to the same thing the canons are cut deeper. The valleys are bogs the hills crags or covered with timber. He came in the dry season & had that advantage. My wagons sink when his passed easily - I crossed his morass by a corduroy - otherwise I should have been stuck

in paying quantities it ought to be found on this creek - I would like to describe the parks through which much of our road passed today but can not do justice - They are very beautiful - The timber on the sides of the canon is better than any I have seen in the Hills - taller straighter & free from ? - This is due to the protected position unclear - a sharp thunder storm this afternoon while we were down the creek - wrapped in our waterproofs we defied

deer seen & killed by this party since arriving among the mts are white-tails -- The canon of Frenck Ck is very fine - walls about 1000 ft & accessible only in a very few places. We have been passing constantly today over & by ledges of quartz, but no gold has been found today by us -  Some of the quartz looks very favorable but there seems little prospect of good placer or gulch mining - If there is gold in these mountains

Camp 17 - June 14 Monday -  Slept like a top. Broke camp at 6 am -- Struck for Custer's trail again & followed it to the Stockade. The country passed through is most beautiful. Open glades in the midst of timbered hills - widening occasionally into parks. The grass is very luxuriant & the timber grows better as we go south. I was far ahead of the command & constantly looking for a good place for my permanent camp. We struck French's Creek about

the rain - Fred's horse strained himself in a mire yesterday. Today he exchanged with a soldier - He is learning to ride very rapidly & went with me over some very bad ground today -  Most of the officers at my camp fire at night. Distance 10 1/2 miles - Wood & good very good & plenty - Water perfecting superb again as I ever tasted, & cold as ice.

Here I proposed to make my camp - While riding around looking for a site which should fill all the requirements I saw some animals & in a moment after a man dashing amongst them ran them into a narrow gorge of the hills - I immediately recognized the insatiable miner - Under the circumstances I had rather not come in contact with these people & shied off. The military have general orders to arrest all citizens found on the Indian Reservation of the

10 1/2 am.  The valley is lovely - a real park - long reaches of the loveliest sward covering hill, valley & ravine. At irregular intervals huge rocks thrust their heads through the green turf & clustered about each such group as if offspring of the unclear is a group of pines towering to the skies -- On every side the valley is shut? in by hills sloping gradually towards the Heavens, their summits crowded with the dark green of the pine -

time I went up to see what had become of him & found him in a little ravine with six of these men - I rode up & one of the men called out "how do you do Colonel" - He had seen me many times he said, but I did not recognize him - His name is Harrison & he knew me at Ft Laramie- I rode up & after speaking to them asked if they knew that they had no business here. The spokesman answered promptly "We do." "Do you know that the military have orders to arrest you?"

Black Hills. I assume that my special orders to escort the scientific people exhonorates me from obedience to the general order for if I have to race around the country looking for miners I must neglect the true object of my trip here - unclear I have not men enough to arrest & send in all these parties without endangering my command -- Still I would rather not meet them - unclear the adj? asked permission to go up & see them & I let him go -  As he did not return in a reasonable

the creek - that they had had a miners meeting yesterday to decide on all doubtful or conflicting points & to settle the amount of land each man might claim -  that their claim averaged three to five unclear per pan from top to bed rock - that not a shovel full of earth was thrown in vain. They are building a water way & hope to get in a flume in a week when they expect to get from 20 to 50 dollars per day to the man - I brought off some of the

"We do" he replied -- I was pleased with the frank manliness of the fellow & said "Well I don't intend to arrest you"-- "Thank you" he answered."- I am very glad to hear it." After that we got into a pleasant conversation & they took me to their claim to show me the gold - The first pan? showed seven colors. The next twelve - & the earth was taken about 2 1/2 feet from the top - not near the bed rock. He told me that there were over 20 miners on

back to meet the wagons - Hurried them up a little & got across the valley ahead of the fire & struck down stream for the stockade - Arrived there about 2 pm - The wagons about half an hour later - The stockade which is about 400 yds from my camp was built last winter by the miners? whom Nix brought out this spring. It is 80 feet square with flanking projections at each corner.  The upright logs are 12 to 14 feet high above the ground - not squared - the openings between the

gold, which I myself saw panned out & brought in with me to send to Genl Crook -- After a very pleasant interview I came away - leaving them very happy -- They had this morning set fire to the grass on their claim to facilitate their work in fixing stakes, etc-  While I was with them the wind arose & the fire spread with great rapidity, so much so as to preclude any possibility of making a camp in this valley near its course - So I determined to come down stream, & went

the defensibility? of the stockade are, first, too few loop holes - second, the loopholes are on a level outside & in- & a dashing enemy might get possession of them - & third, that there are no unclear defenses whatever - Still it is a strong work & a small force could make a good defense against any enemy not possessing artillery - The camp is lovely - a level sward, thick turf - surrounded by low hills & masses of rock -  the hills covered with pines. In front is the pretty

round logs are battened on the inside - not the best arrangement, but adopted from fear a resolute enemy might tear them away if put on the outside - Inside are five cabins strongly built, but very low small & dark & terribly filthy -- The men deserve a great deal of credit for the amount of work done & also for the practically sensible way in which all the preparations for defense were made. The most serious lack is to

appeared an unclear mass of mountains towering to the skies - we have been getting lower ever since if going down stream is any criterion. Yet when we arrive at them they appear crags & buttes of a few hundred feet high - We will test this in a day or two. The country is full of quartz & veins of that mineral are every where to be found  There is no doubt that this country is very rich in both leads & placers? - Jenney will go wild when he

little creek - Plenty of wood splendid water & fine grass ! !  What more can the most fastidious "camper" desire - We have turned Harney's Peak & its contiguous range & are now directly south of them. The country is apparently lower (I have no barometric measurements of today) & the grass & timber are better than two days ago, tho the water is by no means so cold - Yesterday when on "prospect peak", the Harney range

in a few days to the Red Cloud agency - with mail - Fred has been rather under the weather today - caught cold, dabbling in creek yesterday. Miner came down this pm to buy rations - sent in 16 days ago for supplies & has been living on venison without bread or such for that time - We gave him a meal but could furnish no supplies - It is a very hard thing if the greed & rascaility of the Indian unclear shall succeed in preventing the miners

arrives here to find that the soldiers have panned out fifty times more gold today then he has found all the trip - He is terribly jealous & fearful that some one besides himself should discover the gold.  I would not be greatly surprised if todays discoveries  shorten our expedition --- Trout goes back tomorrow with escort of 10 men & six wagons for Jenney & the compy left behind - I shall send out a party

Camp Harney 17 - June 15 - 1875. Got up late - 7 am. Trout started soon after 4 am to bring up name? Wessels? & the scientists - Everybody being glad to rest we did nothing today. The comps washed up & fixed themselves comfortably  shall send in party to Ft Laramie as soon as possible - wrote long letter to Genl Crook in afternoon giving him all the unclear. The camp is lovely - weather warm by day but real cold at night, requiring 2 blankets & a comforter. Went to bed late the young unclear having rather set up unclear

from developing the unclear wealth of this country. The Indians do not use it - There is not a trail to be found . The country is rich in gold in timber & tho the season may be too short for agriculture, it is a most glorious grazing country & will furnish cattle butter & cheese for a nation - I shall arrest no man if I can help it. Distance today 16 1/3 miles - Total distance from Camp Jenney travelled by us 70 2/3 m Actual distance 68 miles

Trout says all the scientific party were at loggerheads last night when he told them of the discovery & showed them the gold - Each abused the other & if you believe all every man of the party is a D-d fool for each says that of the others - Issued orders for Spaulding & Trout to start tomorrow to try & find a good route to the bridge over Beaver Ck - also for a ??  & ten men to go to Ft Laramie for mail - wrote long letter to Genl Bradley - also wrote to

Camp Harney - 18. June 16, 1875 Wednesday. Up at 7 am- After breakfast commenced moving to get to the point selected for permanent residence - across the creek - about 400 yds off - Could do nothing at writing - laid about looking at the working parties - At 2 1/2 pm Wessels reported with his compy & the wagons came in soon after - They have come about 29 miles today - Jenney is terribly disgusted that we should have found the gold before he did - and

moment of confidence told him that the scientific party had found gold some days ago, but that Jenney had bound them to secrecy & they were not to tell the military - The ass !!! There are privates - soldiers in this comd who know more about gold hunting than he can ever hope to learn - I am very glad that we found this gold tho' we are entitled to no credit for it as the miners really found it - Se[??] letter to Genl Crook

Tooty & Father & Mother - also wrote telegrams for Genl Crook for for Tooty to be sent to Genl Bradley - Made tracing of a map for Spaulding by which I am sure he can do his work.  Jenney & several of the unclear over to see me this pm. Jenney is "scooped"--I felt sorry for him, & did not pitch into or crow over him as I might.  But he is a "royal" ass - Trout informs me that one of Jenneys men, in a

top line cut off 
though one does not feel it all the time - a weeks march well fits a man for rest - Made last night a tracing of Custers map for Spaulding & have given him clear direction - I can't see how he can fail - unless the country is absolutely impracticable - Mr Davenport hired a man to take in his dispatches to the Herald. He was to start yesterday morning but alas even the Herald sometimes fails - The men went prospecting & did not get back - So old Joe the guide was subsidised to take in his telegrams ahead of time

Camp Harney - 18 - June 17, 1875. Up late because I was up writing letter until 1 am. Sent Tooty check for $120 for June & July pay to unclear & household expenses -  Spaulding & Trout left about 8 am, kept a man of his back to take up the mail - I hope they will get a good road - Had bough awning put at front of our tents - & am now enjoying its shade - Every thing quiet & all of

Midshipman Easy last night became interested though I've read it a dozen times - & finished it before I put out my lights. Even then I could not sleep til about daylight. It has rained all day - a regular soft spring rain. The weather is somewhat too cold for comfort - Have had quite a unclear today almost all being in to see me -- Came near

with the understanding however that they should not go before mine - Joe is to take in his & mine together - Our new camp is as lovely as an one as I have ever seen - Some rain in afternoon - & it tried to get up a thunderstorm but failed - Evening cold - Had a good nap in afternoon -
Camp Harney June 18 75. Got to reading Mr

& if the man is to blame to tie him up -  Tried to write? on my book today but can't get started again - I think 50 or 100 pages will fix me out & I must get at it - 
Camp Harney June 19 -- Took a long ride this am with Old Bullock Hale & unclear name to examine the country south west. it is more than beautiful. It is very broken & each stream appears

having a stampede this pm - Jenney will not keep his stock tied up - He takes no sort of control over his under staffers? - I ordered the officer of the Day that when he found a horse loose to have him taken up, find out who is responsible for his care, & tying up - investigate the facts & circumstances carefully

June 20 - Camp Harney.  Lovely day - about 930 a party of us started on a sort of picnic to try to get to the top of Harney's Peak. Followed up a little brook for about 4 miles - At a distance Harney & the contiguous range appear to be very high mountains. The nearer you get the smaller they become owing to the fact that

to have thousands of tributary ravines - Each of which is carpeted with splendid grass & looks like an Eastern meadow while the sides of the ravines & tops of all the divides is covered with thick pine. The scenery is charming  tho only wood meadow & rock to make the variety it is not monotonous. We travelled about 20 miles all told, a most excellent wagon road can be easily made - Pretty tired

became dense - Getting up as high as we could on horseback, we tried it on foot - I got high enough & quit - Name? & Davenport got some 300 feet higher to the top of the rocks which crowned our crag - to find themselves very nearly on a level with the highest of these mountains - There is not one of them 1000 feet above the valley Say? 6500 feet above timber but they are very unclear of unclear

there are more or less bare rounded blocks of granite - the ascent is no child's play. We could tell nothing as to the best line of advance - After getting to the foot hills every thing was broken. Huge masses of rock surrounded by pine & on every spot where a little earth could be found the thicket of small pine

June 21 - Monday. The longest day of the year & though a regular Sunday as all days are in the quiet wilderness passed quickly & pleasantly - Did not go out - The day was warm Y the air of that delicious softness that soothes to lazy indifference to all surrounding - Dr Lane came in early in afternoon - Capt Hawley with 2 cos camped 18 miles from him last night. unclear

We all got home again by 1 pm, after a pleasant ride & scramble - Took a good nap - Read Dickens - Chatted & gassed in evening & went to bed 10 1/2 pm. Country very pretty & wild from the unclear base crags & isolated rocks - more gold discoveries --

to bed at 11 pm --
June 22 Tuesday. Beautiful day- at 9 am I was much surprised to see Spaulding coming. Soon after Hawley arrived with the 2 cos 3rd? unclear which were put with camp - Burt with the big train with Trout & Kings Co of 3rd are expected tomorro. Spaulding brought a large

in early tomorro morning - Spaulding & Trout struck Camp Jenney on second day - Why they did not go to the Bridge on Beaver as I directed I can't say - My mail will not get to Ft Laramie as early as I wished - but it will make no difference for the letters. Read Dickens & passed a pleasant day - Tried to write for my book but failed - My brain is too enervated for work -

the Egyptian service - There was no official news of much importance, except that the Indian Chiefs have returned from Washington dissatisfied & that we will probably have a considerable row this summer or fall - It had just as well come now & so far as I am concerned it is the very best time - I have a good command & unless unclear is too smart for me again my stock. I am in a fine condition for what

mail, the first we have had since we left the Rawhide - It was very satisfactory to me - all my loved ones will? - not many letters but one from each point of interest. There are also a good many papers - I am very sorry to lose Bourke who will return by first train to take a years leave of absence to try

with the Interior Department without forfeiting his honor - Should he attempt to bolster up Winchel? he will rue it the longest day of his life.  There are reports of Indians in the Hills - I must give special orders tomorro about the guard & see that the Officer of the Day attends closely to to his work - Today & yesterday we have been visited by flights of grasshoppers - They are from the lower plains as they are full grown even

ever may transpire -  Jenney has been very ill-natured to Bourke & some of the other officers today & accused Custer of having "salted" the gold digging here. The more I see of him the more I am satisfied that his report on the general purport of it was decided upon before he ever came on the expedition - It seems almost impossible for a man to have anything whatever to do

June 23 -Wednesday. Foster came in about 11 am saying the train would be in - not til dark however did the wagons make their appearance - Wrote letters to Tooty, Father & Mother unclear & Genl Bradley - Issued camp orders for the care of the stock - also orders relieving Bourke & Whitman? & ordering them in -

to their wings - while those indigenous are not a fourth of full size & have no wings yet - So far as I have seen this is the only drawback to the Hills - They have eaten every thing at Camp Jenney, & the water there is so horribly alkaline as to make everybody sick - All are delighted to get away from that Camp.  Have not been out of Camp today - writing letters at night -

June 24 - Thursday - Up pretty early - Settled unclear with Bourke - His mess bill was more but I let him off with the $30 he advanced.  Gave the final orders for the moves at 1 pm. Bourke bid us good by & started. He is an intelligent energetic ambitious officer & will make his mark in the world yet -- I am very sorry to lose him. Detailed Lieut Norton as unclear Officer in place

& send escort of 2 NC Off & 12 men - 1 wagon, 1 ambulance. This escort is to take the mail & also return with it -  Intended sending in 10 wagons but will wait till next week - Orders to Hale & his Compy to go on escort with Dr McGillicuddy - Burt & other officers owled? me at night so that I did not get to bed until very late - Trout reports everything is in good order ----

first line cut off & is as invisible as Venus - Jenney goes off tomorro on a pack mule expedition to the North East - He is very decided in his opposition to gold for some reason or other - & I am very sure will not find a particle - Mr John Brown Jr, son of he whose "body lies moldering" went off today - Greatly to the disgust of Trout, who was bitterly opposed to his putting anything into the wagon - I had to "punch" Trout a little, as he was

of Bourke & ordered him to go with Dr McGillicuddy on his topographical expedition tomorro - Had a long talk with Jenney - He wishes to remain here until about 15th July then to push along the west slopes of the Hills to Bear Lodge Butte then around to the North and Eastward. He thinks he will not get through before the 15th October -  unclear Old man Tuttle is just getting

June 25 - Friday. After a great deal of "pattering around" Mr J got off about 1 pm on his journey with pack mules - He is very sneaking about this & in fact about almost everything else & wants to get off by himself so that no one can know whether his report agrees with the facts. One of his reasons for stopping back on Rapid Ck as he told me himself was that he wanted to  work without a lot of soldiers watching every pan

very unreasonable - My new guards are commencing well & if Mr Indian gets any of stock I shall be greatly disappointed - not to say annoyed - I am doing all that can be done to keep it secure -  The wagons are being unloaded today - Have taken the Stockade as a storehouse & it makes a very good one - Ordered 3 wagons 2 pack mules & 35 men with Dr McG - Coles asked leave to go along - wrote a little on my book.

contents of his wagon. The Suttler complained that he also had been robbed, but as investigation showed that his employees were drunk I declined to do anything for his assistance - The soldiers say his men gave them the liquor - The clouds looked very black in the afternoon & there was every appearance of a real old fashioned thunder storm- It passed around however with but little rain - & no "electric phenomenon"- Have written some pages in my book today - It is

of dirt washed out. Dr McGillicuddy got off about 9 am - Hale & the compy followed about 12 - with 3 wagons.  Visited the stockade & examined the condition of storehouses - Everything is very nice - Burt allowed the soldiers to ride in the wagons coming back & several articles are missing - I told him his & Munion's Cos would have to pay for all shortages & gave him a talking to for allowing the soldiers to ride - as it relieved the teamster from

June 16 - Saturday - Fred made his first effort at shooting - He is naturally very timid - having been brought up entirely by women & had as nervous a feeling about firing off a gun as I have about going into a dentist's chair - He fired eight shots at piece of paper - 5 with rest & 3 off hand, at about 30 yds- & rather to my astonishment hit every time - He is delightful & talks about going out squirrel shooting

terribly hard to get started again - Fortunately I have only to write descriptions- The buffalo is my subject now & any one ought to make that interesting at least to sportsmen.  Send my rifle to blacksmith yesterday to get a new double trigger - He said I should have it today - suppose he was too busy shoeing the horses & mules for the scouting parties. Several off's to visit me in evening - wrote afterwards to bed at 12 pm
